Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is only supported by a viral message and a video, without any additional evidence or sources.
Exist alternative explanation: There could be alternative explanations for the claim, such as it being a temporary promotional campaign for the Winter Olympics or a specific event in 2013.
Understate: The claim may understate the limitations of the squats-for-tickets scheme, as it was only operational until December 3, 2013, and was installed at one station on the Moscow subway system.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the squats-for-tickets scheme was only operational until December 3, 2013, and was not a permanent feature in the Moscow metro.
Exaggerate: The claim may exaggerate the effectiveness of 30 squats guaranteeing a free ticket on the Moscow metro, as it was a limited-time promotional campaign and not a regular practice.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing a clear timeline or context for when the squats-for-tickets scheme was implemented and how long it lasted.
Problematic assumption: The claim may make a problematic assumption that the squats-for-tickets scheme was a part of the Citizen Health Plan by the Government, without providing any evidence or confirmation of this connection.
